title: How Iaai says “not”: the preverbal negator caa
introduction: What is negation? It’s how we say that something doesn’t happen, isn’t true, or should not be done. In English, we usually use words like not, don’t/doesn’t, didn’t, can’t, never, or no: “I don’t know,” “They can’t come,” “Never do that.” In English, not typically comes after a helper word (do, can, is) and before the main verb: “do not go,” “is not ready.” In Iaai, the documents show a simple core idea: the negative marker caa goes right before the verb. Example from the documents: e caa ûcû but “it is no longer possible.” You’ll see the same thing in many sentences below.

sections.focus: Core pattern: caa stands right before the verb to say “not”

example.target_sentence: Haba Ciau me ame caa löng hwan.
example.source_sentence: But Ciau did not listen to him.
example.description: The negative word caa is put immediately before the verb (here, “listen”) to make the sentence negative.

example.target_sentence: Bongon ûlabaidru hon veto ka han me walak me ödrumwe caa ûhnyimëködru köu,
example.source_sentence: When they were on that rock, to eat or to play, they were not face to face.
example.description: caa appears right before the verb-like part to say “were not … face to face.”

example.target_sentence: ke caa xanöödra hminya he ka ânyâ ke ûnyi köödru anyin a haba jee thaan Iaai me adreme outöö Draume me oogaanâ.
example.source_sentence: but they could not undertake anything against them because they feared Draume and respected him.
example.description: caa comes directly before the part that carries the action/ability (“could …”), giving “could not.”

example.target_sentence: Aa laba ga haa me öhmwa caa löng hwâm a u moomo.
example.source_sentence: He kept saying that one should not listen to you because you are a woman.
example.description: Again, caa stands right before the verb of “listen,” making it negative (“should not listen”).

example.target_sentence: -Ebë! ame caa musi ötin omoomo, umwe löng?
example.source_sentence: - No! Women must not give us orders. Do you hear?
example.description: caa is placed before the verb part for “give orders,” expressing “must not.”

sections.description: From the provided descriptions, negation in Iaai is made by placing the negative marker caa immediately before the verb in the verbal group. The documents summarize the structure as [Subject] [NEG marker] [Verb] … This is different from English, where not usually follows a helper word (do, can, is). In Iaai, the negator sits right in front of the verb.

sections.focus: Questions and “never”: the same caa pattern

example.target_sentence: Ödrumwe caa hnyi hlingâ lakei Draume me Ihili ka thâân me an a walee latuhödru me anyidru jee lap.
example.source_sentence: They never killed the subjects of Draume and of Ihili to put them in the oven and eat them, because they were their chiefs and their clans.
example.description: The sentence expresses a “never” meaning; caa still appears before the verb area to carry negation.

example.target_sentence: -Ödru ua? adree caa hnyi löng ûthumetu?
example.source_sentence: - Where are they? Haven’t they heard the message?
example.description: In a question, the same placement holds: caa stands right before the verb-like part (“heard”), giving a negative question (“haven’t …?”).

example.target_sentence: e caa ûcû but (from the documents)
example.source_sentence: it is no longer possible
example.description: The documents give this as an example of “no longer”; caa immediately precedes the part translated as “possible.”

sections.description: Whether it’s a statement, a question, or a “never” meaning, the provided materials keep the same idea: put caa right before the verb. This is a stable, easy-to-spot position.

sections.focus: Don’t do it! Negative commands also use caa

example.target_sentence: Caa an ötin wâ enye oo but ke ûnyi ae kong köötin".
example.source_sentence: “Let’s not eat any, for something bad might happen to us.”
example.description: A direct prohibition: the line begins with caa and the action (“eat”). This works like “Don’t …” in English.

example.target_sentence: "öbunenee he ka ijem wanu ke öbune wâ e wakoro me öbunaa caa ijem a öhmu ling.
example.source_sentence: “If, when you are about to drink a coconut, you notice that it is double, do not drink it because we are inside it.”
example.description: Another clear prohibition: caa appears before the verb part translated as “drink,” giving “do not drink.”

example.target_sentence: -Ebë! ame caa musi ötin omoomo, umwe löng?
example.source_sentence: - No! Women must not give us orders. Do you hear?
example.description: This line expresses a strong “must not,” which works like a prohibition; caa stands before the action of “giving orders.”

sections.description: The same caa-before-the-verb pattern shows up in prohibitions (“Don’t …”). This is similar to English “Don’t + verb,” but in Iaai the negative word caa is the one that sits right before the verb.

sections.focus: Word order around the verb: caa can co-occur with other small words

example.target_sentence: e caa ûcû but (from the documents)
example.source_sentence: it is no longer possible
example.description: The documents mention that the negative marker may appear with other particles; here, words follow the verb area, while caa stays immediately before it.

example.target_sentence: Ödrumwe caa hnyi hlingâ lakei Draume me Ihili ...
example.source_sentence: They never killed the subjects of Draume and of Ihili ...
example.description: We see extra words near the verb (the translation gives a “never” meaning). The key point is that caa still directly precedes the verb area.

example.target_sentence: Bongon ûlabaidru ... ödrumwe caa ûhnyimëködru köu,
example.source_sentence: When they were on that rock ... they were not face to face.
example.description: Other particles or complements may appear after the verb; caa remains immediately before the verb part.

example.target_sentence: ke caa xanöödra hminya ...
example.source_sentence: but they could not undertake anything against them ...
example.description: Even with additional material in the clause, caa is kept right in front of the verb-like element it negates.

example.target_sentence: -Ödru ua? adree caa hnyi löng ûthumetu?
example.source_sentence: - Where are they? Haven’t they heard the message?
example.description: In a question with several words, the negative marker still sits directly before the verb area.

sections.description: According to the documents, the negative marker is preverbal and can co-occur with other particles before or after the verb. No matter what else is around, keep your eyes on caa: it goes right before the verb.

sections.focus: Note on other negative-looking lines in our data (without caa)

example.target_sentence: me tubwi ödrin but ke ebë at aa keec mwöötr.
example.source_sentence: and covered them all. Not a single one escaped.
example.description: Negative meaning appears (“not a single one …”), but the form does not show caa.

example.target_sentence: He thibut ödru ke ödree oo thibut eû V̄ekiny me e bë xaca at.
example.source_sentence: They walked as far as Vekiny but, there, there was no one left.
example.description: Negative existential meaning (“no one left”) appears without caa.

example.target_sentence: me ame heleü hnen me bë dok amaa laba hnyin;
example.source_sentence: But again he looked, and he did not find any suitable place.
example.description: Negative meaning (“did not find”) appears without caa in this line.

example.target_sentence: E bë hmetu ûnyi ae soo ka taa hnyi kânâ.
example.source_sentence: There was nothing good to plant anymore.
example.description: “Nothing … anymore” is expressed without caa in this sentence.

example.target_sentence: Haba hnyei V̄ekiny me ame xexe kânâ ke e bë hmetu hnyei.
example.source_sentence: In the land of Vekiny, the ground cracked and there were no more fields.
example.description: “No more fields” is expressed without caa here.

sections.description: The documents state that negation in Iaai is usually with a pre-verb marker like caa. Our sentence list also shows several negative meanings without caa (like “no one,” “nothing,” “no more”). The provided description does not explain these other patterns in detail and notes no further types were covered in the excerpts; it refers to Ozanne-Rivierre (1976: 222–223) for more on preverbal elements. So: learn the core caa-before-verb rule first, and be aware that stories may also use other words for ideas like “no one,” “no more,” or “nothing.”

conclusion: The main takeaway: in Iaai, you say “not” by putting caa right before the verb. This works in statements, questions, and prohibitions, and it can appear alongside other small words. Some lines in the stories show negative meanings without caa (like “no one/ nothing/ no more”), but the provided documents don’t detail those forms here. For now, spot caa right before the verb to read and build basic negative sentences.
